instruction: How do you map soil variability using electromagnetic induction surveys for precision agriculture in the Free State of South Africa?
output: EM38-MK2 surveys in the Free State measure apparent electrical conductivity (ECa) at 0-75 cm and 0-150 cm depths simultaneously. Survey at 12 m transect spacing, recording GPS positions every 2 seconds. ECa correlates with clay content (r=0.87 on Hutton soils) and delineates management zones. Sandy zones (ECa <15 mS/m) need 30% more fertiliser than clay zones (ECa >40 mS/m) due to lower CEC.

instruction: What is the correct soil sampling protocol for nutrient mapping in smallholder farms in western Kenya?
output: Soil sampling in western Kenya uses a stratified random design: divide the field into 0.25 ha blocks, collect 15 cores per block at 0-20 cm depth using a 2.5 cm diameter auger in a W-pattern. Composite the cores, air-dry in the shade for 48 hours, sieve to 2 mm, and submit 500 g subsample. Analyse for pH (1:2.5 water), available P (Mehlich-3), total N (Kjeldahl), exchangeable K, Ca, Mg, and organic carbon (Walkley-Black).

instruction: How do you determine the lime requirement for acid soils in the tea-growing regions of Rwanda?
output: Lime requirement for Rwandan tea soils (Ferralsols, pH 3.8-4.5) is determined by the SMP buffer method: mix 10 g soil with 10 mL SMP buffer solution, shake 30 minutes, read buffer pH. If buffer pH is 5.8, apply 4.5 t/ha agricultural lime (CaCO3 equivalent 85%) to raise pH to 5.5. Incorporate lime to 15 cm depth 3 months before planting. Re-test soil pH annually.

instruction: What is the soil organic carbon sequestration potential of conservation agriculture in the maize belt of Zambia?
output: Conservation agriculture in Zambia (no-till, residue retention, rotation with cowpea) sequesters 0.3-0.5 t C/ha/year in the 0-30 cm layer over 10 years on Acrisols. Baseline SOC in conventionally tilled fields: 8 g/kg. After 10 years of CA: 12 g/kg. The carbon gain stabilises after year 15 as the soil approaches a new equilibrium. Measure SOC by dry combustion (LECO analyser) on 2 mm sieved, carbonate-free samples.

instruction: How do you classify the major soil types in the Ethiopian highlands using the WRB system?
output: Ethiopian highland soils are classified as: Nitisols (deep red clay, pH 5.0-6.0, high P-fixation) on basalt parent material above 2,000 m; Vertisols (black cracking clay, >30% smectite, gilgai microrelief) in flat valley bottoms; Andosols (volcanic ash-derived, low bulk density <0.9 g/cm3, high allophane content) near Rift escarpments; and Leptosols (shallow, <25 cm to bedrock) on steep slopes above 3,000 m.

instruction: What is the phosphorus fixation capacity of Ferralsols in the Congo Basin and how do you manage it?
output: Ferralsols in the Congo Basin fix 85-95% of applied phosphate within 24 hours due to high concentrations of amorphous iron and aluminium oxides (Fed >15%). Management: apply triple superphosphate at 60 kg P2O5/ha banded 5 cm below the seed row (reduces fixation by 40% versus broadcast). Alternatively, apply Minjingu rock phosphate at 250 kg/ha (14% P2O5) as a slow-release source on soils with pH <5.5.

instruction: How do you assess soil compaction in mechanised farms in the Rift Valley of Kenya?
output: Soil compaction is assessed using a cone penetrometer (30-degree cone, 12.83 mm diameter) pushed at 2 cm/s to 60 cm depth. Record penetration resistance every 2.5 cm. Compaction pans form at 20-30 cm depth in Andosols under repeated disc-ploughing, with resistance exceeding 2.5 MPa (root-limiting threshold). Sample at field capacity moisture for comparable readings. Map at 20 m grid spacing.

instruction: What is the correct method for measuring soil infiltration rate using a double-ring infiltrometer in Tanzania?
output: Install the outer ring (60 cm diameter) and inner ring (30 cm) into the soil to 10 cm depth on undisturbed ground. Fill both rings simultaneously to 10 cm depth. Measure water level drop in the inner ring at 1, 2, 5, 10, 15, 20, 30, 45, and 60 minutes, refilling the outer ring to maintain a constant head. Plot cumulative infiltration versus time. Basic infiltration rate for Ferralsols in Morogoro: 25-45 mm/h.

instruction: How do you manage soil salinity in the irrigated perimeters of the Niger River inland delta in Mali?
output: Soil salinity in the Niger inland delta rises to ECe 8-12 dS/m during the dry season when shallow water tables (1.0 m) cause capillary rise. Management: maintain water table below 1.5 m with drainage ditches (1.2 m deep, 30 m spacing). Apply gypsum at 8 t/ha on sodic soils (ESP >20%). Plant salt-tolerant rice variety Gambiaka during the wet season. Monitor salinity quarterly with an EM38 calibrated to ECe.

instruction: What is the role of termites in soil formation and fertility in the savanna soils of Burkina Faso?
output: Macrotermes mounds in Burkina Faso concentrate clay content (35% in mound versus 12% in surrounding soil), exchangeable bases (Ca 8 cmol/kg versus 2), and organic carbon (18 g/kg versus 6). Termite bioturbation creates macropores extending 2 m deep, increasing infiltration by 300%. Farmers spread crushed termite mound material (5 t/ha) onto sandy fields as a soil amendment, raising CEC from 3 to 8 cmol/kg.

instruction: How do you reclaim acid sulphate soils for rice production in the coastal mangrove swamps of Guinea-Bissau?
output: Acid sulphate soils (Thionic Fluvisols, pH 2.5-3.5 when oxidised) in Guinea-Bissau are reclaimed by controlled tidal flushing: construct bunds with sluice gates, flood with seawater at high tide, drain at low tide to leach sulphuric acid. After 3 flushing cycles over 6 weeks, pH rises from 3.0 to 5.0. Apply 4 t/ha agricultural lime and 2 t/ha rock phosphate before transplanting mangrove rice variety WAR-77.

instruction: What is the soil moisture retention curve for typical Vertisols in the cotton-growing areas of Cameroon?
output: Vertisol moisture retention in Cameroon (60% clay, predominantly montmorillonite): field capacity (-33 kPa) = 0.45 m3/m3; permanent wilting point (-1500 kPa) = 0.28 m3/m3; available water capacity = 0.17 m3/m3 or 170 mm/m depth. Saturated hydraulic conductivity is 2-5 mm/h due to swelling clay blocking macropores. Measure retention curve using pressure plate apparatus at 7 pressure steps from -10 to -1500 kPa.

instruction: How do you conduct a soil erosion assessment using the Revised Universal Soil Loss Equation in the highlands of Lesotho?
output: RUSLE for Lesotho highlands: A = R x K x LS x C x P. Rainfall erosivity R = 450 MJ.mm/ha.h.year (from 30-minute maximum intensities). Soil erodibility K = 0.035 t.ha.h/ha.MJ.mm for basalt-derived clay loams. LS factor computed from 30 m DEM slopes (mean 18%). C factor: 0.45 for bare fallow, 0.15 for wheat, 0.01 for dense grass. P factor: 0.5 for contour furrows. Predicted erosion on unprotected slopes: 45 t/ha/year.

instruction: What is the correct procedure for soil texture analysis by the hydrometer method in a laboratory in Uganda?
output: Hydrometer method (Bouyoucos): weigh 50 g air-dried, 2 mm sieved soil into a 600 mL beaker. Add 100 mL of 5% sodium hexametaphosphate (Calgon) dispersing agent, stir, let stand 16 hours. Transfer to a 1 L sedimentation cylinder, fill to mark with distilled water, mix with a plunger for 60 seconds. Read hydrometer (ASTM 152H) at 40 seconds (sand settles) and 2 hours (silt settles). Calculate sand, silt, clay percentages using temperature-corrected readings.

instruction: How do you manage micronutrient deficiencies in calcareous soils of the Nile Valley in Egypt?
output: Calcareous soils (CaCO3 >25%) in the Nile Valley have alkaline pH (8.0-8.5) that renders Fe, Zn, Mn, and Cu unavailable. Manage iron chlorosis in citrus by chelated Fe-EDDHA at 30 g/tree applied to the root zone in spring. Zinc deficiency in maize: foliar ZnSO4 at 0.5% at V6 and V10 stages. Manganese deficiency in wheat: foliar MnSO4 at 0.3% at tillering. DTPA-extractable Zn below 0.8 mg/kg is deficient.

instruction: What is the soil carbon fractionation procedure for assessing organic matter quality in Kenyan Andosols?
output: Carbon fractionation of Kenyan Andosols uses density separation: mix 10 g soil with 50 mL sodium polytungstate (SPT) at 1.6 g/cm3. The floating light fraction (free particulate organic matter, fPOM) is collected, washed, dried, and analysed for C by combustion. The heavy fraction is dispersed ultrasonically (450 J/mL) and re-separated at 1.6 g/cm3 to isolate occluded POM (oPOM). Mineral-associated OM (MAOM) is the residual. Andosols store 60% of SOC as MAOM due to allophane stabilisation.

instruction: How do you interpret a soil profile for land suitability assessment in the sugarcane belt of Mozambique?
output: Soil profile assessment for sugarcane suitability in Mozambique examines: (1) effective depth (>100 cm required, roots penetrate to 150 cm); (2) drainage class (well-drained, no gleying in upper 80 cm); (3) texture (sandy clay loam to clay, AWC >120 mm/m); (4) pH 5.5-7.0; (5) absence of plinthite or petroplinthite within 80 cm. Profile described at 1 m pit with horizon notation (A, Bt1, Bt2, C), Munsell colour, and structure grade.

instruction: What is the nitrogen mineralisation rate in tropical forest soils converted to agriculture in Ghana?
output: Nitrogen mineralisation in newly cleared forest Acrisols in Ghana peaks at 120 kg N/ha/year in Year 1 (flush of labile OM) then declines to 40 kg N/ha/year by Year 5 under continuous maize. Measure by in-situ buried-bag incubation: place 200 g fresh soil in polyethylene bags at 15 cm depth, incubate 28 days, extract with 2M KCl, analyse NH4+ and NO3- by steam distillation. Mineralisation rate = final minus initial inorganic N.

instruction: How do you restore degraded rangeland soils using biochar application in the Kalahari of Botswana?
output: Biochar from Colophospermum mopane wood (pyrolysed at 450 degrees C, 2 h residence) applied at 10 t/ha to degraded Kalahari Arenosols increases water holding capacity from 6% to 11% (w/w), CEC from 2 to 5 cmol/kg, and grass biomass by 65% over 3 growing seasons. Incorporate biochar into the top 10 cm with a disc harrow. Biochar pH 9.2 raises soil pH from 5.2 to 6.1, reducing aluminium toxicity.

instruction: What is the correct method for measuring soil bulk density using the core method in Zambian agricultural soils?
output: Core method: drive a stainless steel cylinder (100 cm3, 5 cm diameter x 5.1 cm height) into the soil at the desired depth using a slide-hammer. Extract the core intact, trim flush with a knife, seal in an aluminium tray, oven-dry at 105 degrees C for 24 hours, and weigh. Bulk density = oven-dry mass divided by core volume. Typical values for Zambian Acrisols: 1.2-1.5 g/cm3 (topsoil), 1.4-1.7 g/cm3 (compacted plough pan at 25 cm).

instruction: How do you manage soil fertility decline under continuous pearl millet production in the sandy soils of Niger?
output: Continuous millet on Nigerien Arenosols depletes soil organic carbon from 3 g/kg to 1.5 g/kg over 15 years and available P from 6 to 2 mg/kg (Bray-1). Management: apply 3 t/ha of composted cattle manure plus 50 kg/ha of SSP (single superphosphate) banded in microdose hills (6 g SSP per planting hill, 10,000 hills/ha). Rotate with cowpea every third year to add 40 kg N/ha via biological fixation.

instruction: What are the diagnostic horizons for identifying Vertisols in the field in the Ethiopian Rift Valley?
output: Vertisol diagnostic features in the Ethiopian Rift: (1) slickensides (polished, grooved surfaces from shrink-swell) visible on ped faces from 30-80 cm depth; (2) wedge-shaped structural aggregates tilted 20-60 degrees from horizontal; (3) surface cracks wider than 1 cm extending to 50 cm depth during the dry season; (4) gilgai microrelief (10-30 cm amplitude undulations at 2-5 m wavelength); (5) clay content exceeding 30% throughout the upper 100 cm (typically 55-65% smectite).

instruction: How do you assess soil biological health using microbial biomass carbon measurement in Tanzanian coffee soils?
output: Microbial biomass carbon (MBC) is measured by chloroform fumigation-extraction: fumigate 25 g fresh soil with ethanol-free CHCl3 for 24 hours in a vacuum desiccator. Extract fumigated and non-fumigated samples with 0.5M K2SO4. Determine organic C in extract by UV-persulfate oxidation. MBC = (Cfumigated - Cunfumigated) / 0.45. Healthy Tanzanian coffee Nitisols: MBC 400-600 mg C/kg soil. Below 200 mg/kg indicates degraded soil biology.

instruction: What is the gypsum requirement for reclaiming sodic soils in the irrigated sugarcane areas of Sudan?
output: Gypsum requirement for Sudanese sodic Vertisols (ESP 35%, target ESP 10%): GR = (ESPi - ESPf) / 100 x CEC x 1.72 (t gypsum/ha for 30 cm depth). With CEC 45 cmol/kg and bulk density 1.3 g/cm3: GR = 0.25 x 45 x 1.72 = 19.4 t/ha. Apply agricultural gypsum (CaSO4.2H2O, 70% purity) adjusted: 19.4 / 0.70 = 27.7 t/ha. Incorporate to 30 cm depth, then leach with 200 mm of good quality water.

instruction: How do you use cover crops to improve soil structure in degraded maize fields in Malawi?
output: Cover crop rotation in Malawi: plant Mucuna pruriens (velvet bean) at 25 kg/ha seed rate after maize harvest in April. Mucuna produces 6 t/ha dry biomass by October, fixing 150 kg N/ha. Slash and incorporate residue 2 weeks before maize planting. After 3 seasons, aggregate stability (wet sieving, >0.25 mm fraction) increases from 35% to 62%, infiltration rate doubles, and bulk density decreases from 1.55 to 1.35 g/cm3.

instruction: What is the soil classification and management of plinthic soils in the Guinea savanna of northern Ghana?
output: Plinthic soils (Plinthosols in WRB, Plinthaquults in USDA) in northern Ghana have a mottled red-yellow Fe-rich plinthite layer at 40-70 cm that hardens irreversibly to ironstone (petroplinthite) if exposed by erosion. Management: never deep-plough below 30 cm. Maintain vegetative cover year-round. If ironstone already exposed, break with a ripper to 50 cm every 3 years, apply 5 t/ha compost to improve structure above the pan.

instruction: How do you conduct a mini-pit soil survey for farm-level land use planning in rural Uganda?
output: Mini-pit survey: at each sampling point (50 m grid), dig a 30x30x50 cm pit with a hoe. Record horizon boundaries, colour (Munsell chart), texture (hand feel: ribbon test for clay content), structure (granular, blocky, massive), root abundance, mottling, and effervescence with 10% HCl (indicates carbonates). Record GPS coordinates and slope angle. Map 20-30 pits per hectare. Group similar soils into management zones for crop allocation.

instruction: What is the cation exchange capacity measurement procedure for tropical soils with variable charge in Cameroon?
output: Variable-charge tropical soils require CEC measurement at field pH, not the standard pH 7 ammonium acetate method which overestimates CEC. Use the compulsive exchange method: saturate with 0.01M BaCl2 at field pH (3 washings), then displace Ba with 0.005M MgSO4. CEC = (initial Mg - final Mg) expressed in cmol(+)/kg. Typical CEC for Cameroon Ferralsols: 3-8 cmol/kg at field pH 4.5, versus 12-15 cmol/kg if measured at pH 7.

instruction: How do you manage waterlogged Gleysols for crop production in the Kafue Flats of Zambia?
output: Gleysols in the Kafue Flats have grey-blue (gley) colours (10GY 5/1 to 5BG 5/1) below 20 cm indicating permanent saturation. Management for rice: maintain flood at 5-10 cm depth during growing season, drain 2 weeks before harvest. For upland crops: construct raised beds 30 cm high, 1.2 m wide, with 30 cm drainage furrows between beds. Install subsurface drains at 80 cm depth if conversion to vegetables is planned.

instruction: What is the soil potassium dynamics in banana plantations on volcanic soils in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo?
output: Banana on DRC volcanic Andosols removes 450 kg K/ha/year in bunches. Exchangeable K declines from 1.8 to 0.4 cmol/kg over 5 years without replenishment. Non-exchangeable K (HNO3-extractable) in fresh volcanic ash provides a reserve of 800 mg/kg but releases slowly (15 mg/kg/year). Apply muriate of potash (KCl) at 600 kg/ha/year split into 3 applications. Monitor K/Mg ratio; below 0.3 induces Mg-induced K deficiency symptoms.

instruction: How do you determine soil water storage capacity for rainfed crop planning in the semi-arid Dodoma region of Tanzania?
output: Soil water storage for Dodoma sandy loams (Cambisols): measure available water capacity (AWC) as field capacity minus wilting point using pressure plate apparatus. AWC = 0.12 m3/m3 for the sandy loam topsoil (0-30 cm) and 0.09 m3/m3 for the sandy clay loam subsoil (30-80 cm). Total plant-available storage in 80 cm profile: (0.12 x 300) + (0.09 x 500) = 81 mm. A 400 mm seasonal rainfall with 65% effective fraction supplies 260 mm, adequate for 90-day sorghum.

instruction: What is the role of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi in phosphorus uptake in the acidic soils of the West African forest zone?
output: AMF (predominantly Glomus and Acaulospora spp.) extend the root depletion zone for P from 1-2 mm to 80 mm via external hyphae networks. In acidic Ferralsols (available P <5 mg/kg Bray-1), AMF-colonised maize absorbs 3x more P than non-colonised plants. Inoculation with Rhizophagus irregularis at 500 spores per planting hole increases maize yield by 35% on P-deficient soils. Excess P fertilisation (>30 kg P/ha) suppresses AMF colonisation.

instruction: How do you build a compost heap using the Indore method for smallholder farms in Zimbabwe?
output: The Indore composting method: layer crop residues (15 cm), fresh cattle manure (5 cm), and topsoil (2 cm) in a 2 x 3 x 1.5 m pit. Add water to achieve 55-65% moisture (squeeze test: a few drops emerge). Turn the heap at day 15 and day 30. Mature compost (C:N below 20:1, dark brown, earthy smell) is ready in 60-90 days. Apply at 5-10 t/ha for maize. One cattle kraal produces enough manure for 0.5 ha/year.

instruction: What is the soil degradation assessment framework for the drylands of the Horn of Africa?
output: LADA (Land Degradation Assessment in Drylands) framework for the Horn: assess 5 indicators at 1 km resolution: (1) vegetation cover decline (NDVI trend analysis, 20-year Landsat); (2) soil organic carbon loss (>25% decline = severe); (3) soil erosion by water (RUSLE-modelled, >12 t/ha/year = high); (4) wind erosion (dust flux from MODIS aerosol data); (5) salinisation (ECe >4 dS/m in irrigated areas). Assign degradation class: slight, moderate, severe, very severe.

instruction: How do you test for soil contamination by heavy metals in urban agriculture plots in Nairobi, Kenya?
output: Sample at 0-20 cm depth along a 5 m grid (10 samples per 100 m2 plot). Digest 1 g oven-dried, <0.5 mm soil in aqua regia (3:1 HCl:HNO3) at 110 degrees C for 2 hours. Analyse Pb, Cd, Cr, and As by ICP-OES. WHO/FAO limits for agricultural soil: Pb <100 mg/kg, Cd <3 mg/kg, Cr <150 mg/kg, As <20 mg/kg. Nairobi roadside plots frequently exceed Pb limits (mean 180 mg/kg) due to historical leaded petrol deposition.

instruction: What is the effect of termite mound soil on seedling establishment in dryland restoration in Namibia?
output: Termite mound soil from Macrotermes michaelseni in Namibian dryland has 2.5x higher water-holding capacity, 3x higher available P, and pH 7.2 versus 5.5 for surrounding Arenosol. Mixing mound soil at 20% by volume with native soil in planting holes increases seedling survival of Acacia erioloba from 25% to 72% over the first dry season. The enriched soil also contains beneficial Bacillus spp. that enhance root colonisation.

instruction: How do you assess aluminium toxicity in the subsoil of Acrisols in the tea regions of southern Malawi?
output: Aluminium toxicity assessment: sample subsoil at 20-40 and 40-60 cm depths. Extract exchangeable Al with 1M KCl (30-minute shake). Determine Al by ICP-OES. Calculate Al saturation: (exch. Al / effective CEC) x 100. Tea tolerates up to 60% Al saturation, but most crops show root restriction above 20%. In Thyolo District, Al saturation at 40-60 cm averages 75% on Acrisols with pH(KCl) 3.9. Ameliorate with deep-placed lime (pelleted, 2 t/ha at 30 cm depth using a ripper).

instruction: What is the laboratory procedure for determining plant-available phosphorus by the Olsen method in calcareous soils of North Africa?
output: Olsen P extraction: shake 2.5 g air-dried, 2 mm sieved soil with 50 mL of 0.5M NaHCO3 (pH 8.5) for 30 minutes on a reciprocal shaker at 180 rpm. Filter through Whatman No. 42 paper. Determine P concentration by molybdate-blue colorimetry at 882 nm. Convert to mg P/kg soil. Interpretation for North African calcareous soils: <5 mg/kg = deficient, 5-15 mg/kg = marginal, 15-30 mg/kg = adequate, >30 mg/kg = excessive. Olsen method is preferred over Bray for soils with pH >7.

instruction: How do you diagnose and manage iron toxicity in lowland rice soils of Sierra Leone?
output: Iron toxicity in Sierra Leone inland valley swamp rice occurs when reduced Fe2+ in soil solution exceeds 300 mg/L (normal: <100 mg/L), causing leaf bronzing from tip downwards. Diagnose by soil solution sampling using lysimeters at 15 cm depth. Manage by mid-season drainage (lower water table for 5 days to re-oxidise Fe), applying 2 t/ha lime to raise pH above 5.5, and planting tolerant varieties (ROK 16, NERICA-L 19) with Fe-exclusion root mechanisms.

instruction: What is the soil carbon stock estimation method for national greenhouse gas inventories in East Africa?
output: SOC stock estimation follows IPCC Tier 2 approach: sample at fixed depths (0-30 and 30-100 cm) at 50 points per land-use stratum (forest, cropland, grassland, wetland). Determine OC by dry combustion (LECO CN628), bulk density by core method. SOC stock (t C/ha) = OC (g/kg) x BD (g/cm3) x depth (cm) / 10. Correct for gravel fraction (>2 mm). Typical stocks: montane forest 180 t C/ha (0-100 cm), cropland 80 t C/ha, degraded grassland 45 t C/ha.

instruction: How do you manage soil crusting to improve seedling emergence in the sandy soils of the Sahel?
output: Surface crusting on Sahelian sandy soils (low OM, dispersive silt) reduces infiltration to <5 mm/h and prevents seedling emergence. Management: apply 2 t/ha of millet stalk mulch on the surface after sowing to break raindrop impact. Alternatively, incorporate 500 kg/ha of composted manure into the top 5 cm before sowing. Use scarifying implements (daba hoe with 3 tines) after each heavy rain to break the crust. Crusting reduces emergence from 85% to 30%.

instruction: What is the procedure for soil aggregate stability analysis using the wet sieving method in South African soils?
output: Wet sieve analysis (Yoder method): air-dry soil aggregates (1-2 mm size class), place 25 g on the top sieve of a nest (2, 1, 0.5, 0.25, 0.106 mm). Submerge in water and oscillate vertically (30 cycles/minute, 1.3 cm stroke) for 5 minutes. Oven-dry each fraction at 105 degrees C. Calculate mean weight diameter (MWD) = sum of (fraction mass x mean diameter). Well-structured Hutton soils: MWD >1.5 mm. Degraded soils: MWD <0.5 mm.

instruction: How do you manage saline seeps caused by dryland salinity in the wheat belt of western Kenya?
output: Saline seeps in western Kenya form where perched water tables intersect slopes, bringing dissolved salts to the surface (ECe 8-15 dS/m). Management: (1) plant deep-rooted perennial grasses (Napier, Rhodes grass) in the recharge zone upslope to lower the water table; (2) install a cut-off drain (60 cm deep) above the seep to intercept lateral flow; (3) apply gypsum (5 t/ha) to the seep area and plant salt-tolerant Eragrostis tef as the first crop.

instruction: What is the recommended soil management for avocado orchards on Nitisols in the central highlands of Kenya?
output: Avocado on Kenyan Nitisols (Kiambu County): maintain pH 5.5-6.5 with annual lime application (1-2 t/ha based on buffer pH test). Apply 15 t/ha compost annually as a 10 cm mulch ring (1 m from trunk to drip line). Nitisols fix P strongly: apply 80 kg P2O5/ha as DAP banded at 30 cm depth in a ring at the drip line. Do not waterlog: Nitisols have good structure but avocado roots are susceptible to Phytophthora cinnamomi above 30% soil moisture.

instruction: How do you interpret an exchangeable sodium percentage map for irrigation planning in the Awash Basin of Ethiopia?
output: ESP map interpretation for Awash Basin irrigation: ESP <6% = non-sodic, suitable for all crops; ESP 6-15% = slightly sodic, use gypsum amendment and grow moderately tolerant crops (wheat, barley); ESP 15-25% = sodic, reclamation required before cropping (gypsum at calculated rate, deep ploughing); ESP >25% = severely sodic, not economically reclaimable for annual cropsâ€”consider salt-tolerant perennials (Atriplex, Sesbania) or aquaculture.

instruction: What is the impact of continuous sugarcane monoculture on soil structure in the KwaZulu-Natal midlands of South Africa?
output: Forty years of sugarcane monoculture on KwaZulu-Natal Oxisols degrades soil structure: macro-aggregate stability declines from 78% (virgin grassland) to 42% (continuous cane), bulk density increases from 1.15 to 1.45 g/cm3, and saturated hydraulic conductivity drops from 65 to 12 mm/h. SOC declines from 38 to 22 g/kg. Remediation: fallow with oats-vetch rotation for 2 seasons, apply 20 t/ha filter cake, and adopt minimum tillage with GPS-guided traffic.

instruction: How do you assess the soil seed bank for weed management planning in conservation agriculture in Mozambique?
output: Soil seed bank assessment: collect 20 soil cores (5 cm diameter x 10 cm depth) per field in a stratified random pattern. Bulking and mix thoroughly. Spread 500 g in a thin layer (1 cm) on sterilised sand in greenhouse trays. Water daily. Count and identify emerging seedlings weekly for 12 weeks, removing each after identification. Typical seed bank in conventional-till maize: 8,000-25,000 seeds/m2. CA fields after 5 years: 3,000-8,000 seeds/m2 due to reduced soil disturbance.

instruction: How do you measure soil respiration rates to assess biological activity in restored wetland soils in the Okavango Delta of Botswana?
output: Soil respiration is measured using a static alkali absorption method: place a jar containing 20 mL of 0.5M NaOH inside a sealed PVC chamber (20 cm diameter) pressed 3 cm into the soil. Incubate 24 hours. Titrate residual NaOH with 0.1M HCl after precipitating carbonate with BaCl2. CO2 flux = (blank - sample) x acid normality x 22 / (area x time). Restored Okavango wetland soils: 35-60 mg CO2/m2/h (wet season), 8-15 mg CO2/m2/h (dry season). Rates correlate with soil moisture content (r=0.82).

instruction: What is the effect of different tillage systems on soil porosity and root penetration in the clay soils of the Gezira Scheme in Sudan?
output: Conventional disc ploughing on Gezira Vertisols creates a plough pan at 15-18 cm depth with total porosity dropping from 52% to 38% and macroporosity (>60 micrometres) from 12% to 3%. Sorghum root density below the pan is only 0.2 cm/cm3 versus 1.5 cm/cm3 above. Deep chiselling to 40 cm once every 3 years restores subsoil macroporosity to 9% and root penetration to 0.8 cm/cm3. Measure porosity from undisturbed cores using water desorption at 0, -1, -3, -6, and -10 kPa.

instruction: How do you establish soil fertility benchmarks for the major agroecological zones of Nigeria?
output: Soil fertility benchmarking for Nigeria requires collecting 200 georeferenced topsoil samples (0-20 cm) per agroecological zone using a stratified random design across the Sudan Savanna (pH 6.5, OC 4 g/kg, Bray-P 8 mg/kg), Guinea Savanna (pH 5.8, OC 8 g/kg, Bray-P 5 mg/kg), Forest-Savanna Transition (pH 5.5, OC 12 g/kg, Bray-P 4 mg/kg), and Humid Forest (pH 4.8, OC 18 g/kg, Bray-P 3 mg/kg). Analyse by mid-infrared spectroscopy for rapid throughput (500 samples/day) with 15% wet chemistry calibration subset.
